update.description:
See issue #164.

‌

How to test it?

1. Launch VRX:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo dock.launch verbose:=true
```

1. Launch the teleoperation node:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo usv_joydrive.launch
```

1. Dock the WAM-V in the bay with the red circle \(incorrect one\) and check score:

```
rostopic echo /vrx/task/info
```

The simulation should stop and you should observe a score of 10 points. If you repeat the test and dock in the bay with the red cross \(correct one\), you should observe a score of 20 points.
update.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

content.raw:
Looks good to me.  I’ll work on updating the tutorial wiki and documentation to explain all of this.  Shall we wait till we finish explaining it to merge?  Technical it looks great.

I was considering adding a ROS publication of docking state to help with debugging - will only do that if I can find extra time.  Do you think it would be worthwhile?
content.html:
Looks good to me. I’ll work on updating the tutorial wiki and documentation to explain all of this. Shall we wait till we finish explaining it to merge? Technical it looks great.

I was considering adding a ROS publication of docking state to help with debugging - will only do that if I can find extra time. Do you think it would be worthwhile?

pullrequest.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

content.raw:
Status:

1. I think I addressed it in [PR190](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/190/relative-bay-visualization/diff)
2. I don’t have an easy solution.  Could extend the activation zone, but them teams would be able to jam the vehicle into the front of the dock.
3. I changed to using the floating dock in PR190
4. Addressed in PR190
5. Recommend changing the Task Description document.  No penalty for collisions with the dock.

‌
content.html:
Status:

  1. I think I addressed it in PR190
  2. I don’t have an easy solution. Could extend the activation zone, but them teams would be able to jam the vehicle into the front of the dock.
  3. I changed to using the floating dock in PR190
  4. Addressed in PR190
  5. Recommend changing the Task Description document. No penalty for collisions with the dock.

‌

content.raw:
Getting back to this.

This may be bad form, but I put a PR onto this branch to address some of the items above - see [PR190](#!/osrf/vrx/pull-requests/190/relative-bay-visualization/diff)  The PR adds console messages \(gzmsgs\) to help debug.  The intention with the messages is that we provide state information.  Here is an image of the terms I’m using for states of the docking procedure.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/BgXLzgM/images/3600844695-new_doc_2019-10-01_12.02.38_1.jpg)
‌

pull_request.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

pullrequest.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

content.raw:
I was able to successfully verify that things work as expected - thank you for the tutoring.  A few thoughts

1. I found debugging this to be challenging - perhaps…

    1. Change the OnActivationEvent\(\) standard output in the scan\_dock\_scoring\_plugin to gzmsg instead of gzdbg \(Line 211\)
    2. I had to comment out the collision gzdbg messages in the scoring\_plugin \(Line 301\) to avoid spamming the terminal with output, making it hard to find the activation events.
    3. Is there an easy way to have gzmsg’s go to the screen, but not gzdbg?  I believe verbose turns them both on.  The OnActiviationEvent\(\) messages were really helpful.
    
2. To successfully dock, the OnActivationEvent needs to stay at 1 for 10 seconds and then needs to transition back to 0.  The intention is for teams to exit the dock \(back out\) - but if teams drive forward after staying in the containment for 10 seconds, that also currently counts as a successful docking.

    1. How hard would it be to enforce that they exit the dock from the way the entered - rather than driving forward to exit the containment?
    
3. Currently the example dock.world.xacro uses the static dock - should we switch to the dynamic \(floating\) dock?
4. The visualization of the activation zones would be helpful, but currently the location for those are specified in global gazebo coordinates - created an issue to fix that separate from this PR: [#!/osrf/vrx/issues/171/docking-activation-zone-improvement](#!/osrf/vrx/issues/171/docking-activation-zone-improvement)
5. Currently in the Task Description we say “Successful docking consists of having the USV fully enter the dock, stay within the dock area for 10 s and then exit the dock without hitting it.”  I think we should remove the “without hitting it”.  If I read the plugin correctly, the DockChecker timer isn’t affected by collisions, which is fine.  Trying to dock without touching the sides would be too tough!

Sorry for all the items.  I can work on these, just have to run at the moment.

‌
content.html:
I was able to successfully verify that things work as expected - thank you for the tutoring. A few thoughts

  1. I found debugging this to be challenging - perhaps…

    1. Change the OnActivationEvent() standard output in the scan_dock_scoring_plugin to gzmsg instead of gzdbg (Line 211)
    2. I had to comment out the collision gzdbg messages in the scoring_plugin (Line 301) to avoid spamming the terminal with output, making it hard to find the activation events.
    3. Is there an easy way to have gzmsg’s go to the screen, but not gzdbg? I believe verbose turns them both on. The OnActiviationEvent() messages were really helpful.

  2. To successfully dock, the OnActivationEvent needs to stay at 1 for 10 seconds and then needs to transition back to 0. The intention is for teams to exit the dock (back out) - but if teams drive forward after staying in the containment for 10 seconds, that also currently counts as a successful docking.

    1. How hard would it be to enforce that they exit the dock from the way the entered - rather than driving forward to exit the containment?

  3. Currently the example dock.world.xacro uses the static dock - should we switch to the dynamic (floating) dock?

  4. The visualization of the activation zones would be helpful, but currently the location for those are specified in global gazebo coordinates - created an issue to fix that separate from this PR: #!/osrf/vrx/issues/171/docking-activation-zone-improvement
  5. Currently in the Task Description we say “Successful docking consists of having the USV fully enter the dock, stay within the dock area for 10 s and then exit the dock without hitting it.” I think we should remove the “without hitting it”. If I read the plugin correctly, the DockChecker timer isn’t affected by collisions, which is fine. Trying to dock without touching the sides would be too tough!

Sorry for all the items. I can work on these, just have to run at the moment.

‌

pull_request.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

pullrequest.title: Fixing dock scoring plugin for Gazebo 9

content.raw:
If you run it with verbose enabled, you should see messages like these, when there’s a new state change:

```
[Dbg] [scan_dock_scoring_plugin.cc:211] [bay1] OnActivationEvent(): 1
[Dbg] [scan_dock_scoring_plugin.cc:211] [bay1] OnActivationEvent(): 0
```

`1` means that the WAM-V is currently docked. `0` means is not docked. Keep in mind that if you go all the way in touching the dock, that’s not considered valid. Then, you need to stay there for 10 seconds, and then, undock.

If you install `ignition-tools`, you can also introspect directly the Ignition Transport topics:

```
/vrx/dock_2018/bay_1/contain
/vrx/dock_2018/bay_2/contain
```

with:

```
ign topic -e -t /vrx/dock_2018/bay_1/contain
```

‌
content.html:
If you run it with verbose enabled, you should see messages like these, when there’s a new state change:

[Dbg] [scan_dock_scoring_plugin.cc:211] [bay1] OnActivationEvent(): 1
[Dbg] [scan_dock_scoring_plugin.cc:211] [bay1] OnActivationEvent(): 0

1 means that the WAM-V is currently docked. 0 means is not docked. Keep in mind that if you go all the way in touching the dock, that’s not considered valid. Then, you need to stay there for 10 seconds, and then, undock.

If you install ignition-tools, you can also introspect directly the Ignition Transport topics:

/vrx/dock_2018/bay_1/contain
/vrx/dock_2018/bay_2/contain

with:

ign topic -e -t /vrx/dock_2018/bay_1/contain

‌

content.raw:
I can’t seem to replicate the test.  I updated my docker container \(gazebo version 9.11.0\).  When I teleop into the dock there is no evidence \(score or gazebo message\) of the container plugin sending traffic.

I suspect it might be a setup event on my end - but I’m a bit at a loss.

Also, b/c the dock is so far away, it takes awhile to run each test.
content.html:
I can’t seem to replicate the test. I updated my docker container (gazebo version 9.11.0). When I teleop into the dock there is no evidence (score or gazebo message) of the container plugin sending traffic.

I suspect it might be a setup event on my end - but I’m a bit at a loss.

Also, b/c the dock is so far away, it takes awhile to run each test.

update.description:
See issue #164.

‌

How to test it?

1. Launch VRX:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo dock.launch verbose:=true
```

1. Launch the teleoperation node:

```
roslaunch vrx_gazebo usv_joydrive.launch
```

1. Dock the WAM-V in the bay with the red circle \(incorrect one\) and check score:

```
rostopic echo /vrx/task/info
```

The simulation should stop and you should observe a score of 10 points. If you repeat the test and dock in the bay with the red cross \(correct one\), you should observe a score of 20 points.
